Tokyo is UTC+9, so it’s likely still February 19 there from the user’s perspective. **Selecting key stories for the summary**

I’ll also include the preview for SusHi Tech. I already have the necessary sources lined up, so now I just need to compose a concise and clear answer that pulls all this together.

annotations.title: Rakuten, Google to Collaborate in Product Promotion via YouTube
Sony brings virtual production hub to Tokyo with new creator base
MITSUI E&S wins electric crane order for Port of Tokyo
Tokyo stocks end higher on tech shares, weaker yen
SusHi Tech Tokyo 2026 set to be largest yet - The Japan Times
Cambridge music-tech startup to represent city at Tokyo innovation gathering

content.text:
As of February 19, 2026 in Tokyo, notable tech‑related news includes:

1. **Rakuten–Google YouTube collaboration announced in Tokyo**  
   Rakuten Group and Google announced a new partnership in Tokyo to promote products via YouTube, combining Rakuten’s e‑commerce platform with Google’s video advertising and analytics capabilities. The aim is to drive more targeted shopping and marketing experiences for Japanese consumers. ([nippon.com](https://www.nippon.com/en/news/yjj2026021900827/?utm_source=openai))  

2. **Sony opening a major virtual‑production hub in Tokyo**  
   Sony is establishing its third global Digital Media Production Center (DMPC) in Tokyo this month, focused on virtual production and high‑end content creation. The new base will support creators using LED walls, real‑time engines, and other advanced production tech, positioning Tokyo as a key node in Sony’s global creator network. ([marketech-apac.com](https://marketech-apac.com/sony-brings-virtual-production-hub-to-tokyo-with-new-creator-base/?utm_source=openai))  

3. **Electric, low‑emission cranes ordered for Port of Tokyo**  
   MITSUI E&S has received an order from Tokyo Port Terminal Corporation for new electric container cranes at the Port of Tokyo. These cranes are part of efforts to modernize port operations with cleaner, more energy‑efficient equipment, reflecting ongoing infrastructure tech upgrades in the city. ([porttechnology.org](https://www.porttechnology.org/mitsui-es-wins-electric-crane-order-for-port-of-tokyo/?utm_source=openai))  

4. **Tokyo’s stock market lifted by heavyweight tech shares**  
   On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei and Topix indices closed higher, led by gains in major technology names such as Tokyo Electron and Shin‑Etsu Chemical. Optimism around AI‑related demand and a weaker yen helped boost these tech and export‑oriented stocks. ([english.news.cn](https://english.news.cn/asiapacific/20260219/eff32c8d94cc4de090c79a04059a3dad/c.html?utm_source=openai))  

5. **Tokyo gearing up for large‑scale startup/tech events**  
   - **SusHi Tech Tokyo 2026**: Coverage from yesterday highlights that this year’s edition (in April) is expected to be the largest yet, with a heavy focus on AI, robotics, resilience, and entertainment, and participation from over 700 startups. ([japantimes.co.jp](https://www.japantimes.co.jp/business/2026/02/18/sushi-teck-preview/?utm_source=openai))  
   - A Cambridge (U.S.) music‑tech startup was also reported today as heading to a Tokyo innovation gathering, underscoring the city’s pull for international tech and creative companies. ([cambridgeday.com](https://www.cambridgeday.com/2026/02/19/tactus-takes-on-tokyo/?utm_source=openai))  

If you’d like, I can narrow this down to consumer‑oriented news (phones, gadgets, apps) or focus on startup/venture news specifically in Tokyo.
